title: Figma launches three AI image tools to keep designers out of Photoshop

paragraphs.content: Figma has introduced three new AI-powered image editing tools—**Erase object**, **Isolate object**, and **Expand image**—designed to give designers more precise control without leaving the design canvas.Rolled into a new contextual image editing toolbar, the features allow users to remove elements, isolate subjects, and extend backgrounds directly inside Figma Design and Figma Draw.The tools were announced on December 10, 2025, and are positioned as a way to eliminate the back-and-forth between Figma and external editors for everyday production work.

paragraphs.content: The new capabilities are part of Figma’s broader AI push, which already includes background removal, AI-assisted image generation, and other smart editing features.Figma says the updates are available to Full seat users on Professional, Organization, and Enterprise plans with AI enabled, with plans to expand access across more products in 2026.Release notes emphasize that the contextual toolbar centralizes all AI image actions in one place, aiming to speed up routine tasks like resizing hero images or cleaning up product shots.

sections.title: How Erase, Isolate, and Expand reshape everyday image workflows

paragraphs.content: Erase object lets designers lasso and remove specific items from a scene while preserving the surrounding background, targeting common tasks like stripping out distracting props in product photography.Isolate object uses AI to detect a subject—such as a person or product—so it can be restyled, recolored, or repositioned without affecting the original backdrop.Expand image, meanwhile, extends an image’s background to new aspect ratios, allowing teams to adapt a single hero asset from desktop to mobile or social formats without obvious stretching or cropping compromises.

paragraphs.content: Figma’s blog describes these features as closing the loop on “time-consuming processes” that previously required exporting to other tools and reimporting assets into design files.In the official promo, the company highlights how the toolbar groups newer AI options with existing tools like Remove background and resolution boost to support a more “complete creative workflow” inside Figma.Early walkthroughs from creators show the tools handling common UI, marketing, and thumbnail scenarios smoothly, particularly when expanding simple backgrounds or isolating clear foreground subjects.

sections.title: Early reaction: big workflow gains, but Photoshop still safe

paragraphs.content: Content creators who tested the update praised the speed and convenience of the new tools, arguing that many routine edits no longer justify a round trip to Photoshop.One reviewer noted that Erase object and Isolate object “remove a lot of friction” for tasks like cleaning up UI screenshots or swapping backgrounds in marketing visuals, even if they are not perfect in every edge case.At the same time, testers reported that the tools could struggle with more complex scenes, such as intertwined objects or challenging shadows, where traditional image editors still offer finer control.

Figma presents these releases as part of a larger AI strategy that includes text, diagramming, and code-focused features, signaling ambitions to become a more end-to-end creative platform.The company’s release notes frame the AI toolbar as a foundation for future capabilities, suggesting further integrations and refinements are likely as models improve and more users adopt the tools.Analysts and creators alike see the current update less as a “Photoshop killer” and more as a significant quality-of-life upgrade that could cover the majority of everyday image edits inside collaborative design workflows.
